name: Enable SAML Single Sign-on (SSO) For Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS)
title: Enable SAML Single Sign-on (SSO) For Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS)
body:
This article will instruct you on how to set up and enable SAML on your account so that your users can quickly and easily log in to take their KnowBe4 training using AD FS. For more information on AD FS, see Microsoft's Create a Relying Party Trust article and read each of the below three sections.

Note: Make sure the email address that your users use to authenticate with SAML is either entered into the Email field or Email Aliases field of their user profile. However, only the email address listed in the Email field will receive training notification emails. For more information about adding information to user profiles, visit our User Profile Guide.

How to Set Up SAML

To set up SAML, follow the steps below:

  1. Access your AD FS management console.
  2. Expand the Trust Relationships folder.
  3. Right-click Relying Party Trust and click Add Relying Party Trust…. When you click, the Add Relying Party Trust window will open.

  4. Click Start on the wizard’s Welcome screen.

  5. Choose Enter data about the relying party manually. Click Next.

  6. Enter a display name, such as KnowBe4. Select Next.

  7. Leave AD FS profile selected and select Next.

  8. On the Configure Certificate screen, select Next.

  9. On the Configure URL screen, select the Enable support for the SAML 2.0 WebSSO protocol option. Stay on the Configure URL screen and move on to the next step.
  10. For this step, you'll need to obtain your unique Callback URL from your KSAT Account Settings:
    1. Log in to your KSAT account.
    2. After logging in, select your email address at the top-right corner of the page.
    3. Select Account Settings.
    4. Navigate to Account Integrations > SAML.
    5. Copy your account-specific callback URL. For example, https://training.knowbe4.com/auth/saml/xxxxxxxxxxx/callback.
    6. Navigate back to the Configure URL screen of the setup wizard.
    7. Paste the link you obtained into the Relying party SAML 2.0 SSO service URL field on the Configure URL page and select Next.

  11. On the Configure Identifiers screen, enter "KnowBe4" into the Relying party trust identifier field. Select Add, then select Next.

  12. Leave the I do not want to configure multi-factor authentication settings for this relying party trust at this time option selected, then select Next.

  13. Leave the Permit all users to access this relying party option selected, then select Next.

  14. On the Ready to Add Trust screen, select Next.

  15. Leave the Open the Edit Claim Rules dialog for this relying party trust when the wizard closes check box selected and select Close.

  16. In the Edit claim rules window, select Add Rule….

  17. On the Choose Rule Type screen, leave Send LDAP Attributes as Claims selected as the template and select Next.

  18. Enter a name, then under Attribute Store choose Active Directory. Under the Mapping of LDAP attributes to outgoing claim types area, select Email Addresses for the LDAP Attribute and then choose E-mail Address for Outgoing Claim Type. Click Finish.

  19. Click Add Rule... back on the Edit Claims window again.

  20. Under Claim rule template, select Transform an Incoming Claim and select Next.

  21. Enter a name and then change the following settings:
    • Incoming claim type: Select E-Mail Address.
    • Outgoing claim type: Select Name ID.
    • Outgoing name ID format: Select Email.
    • Pass through all claim values: Select this option.

  22. Select Finish on the Configure Claim Rule page, and then select OK on the Edit Claims window to exit.
  23. Right-click the relying party trust and select Properties.

  24. Click the Advanced tab and select SHA-256 from the Secure hash algorithm drop-down menu.

  25. Select OK to exit.

How to Find the SHA1 Thumbprint

To find the SHA1 thumbprint, follow the steps below:

  1. Open AD FS Management.
  2. Select the Certificates folder under Service.
  3. Select the Token-signing certificate.

  4. Select the Details tab.
  5. Select the Thumbprint option.

  6. Copy your unique thumbprint.

How to Enable SAML

The final step is to enable SAML on your account. To learn how to enable SAML on your account, please visit our Set Up SAML Single Sign-on (SSO) for the Security Awareness Training Console article. For more information on the AD FS LoginToRp parameter that is part of your target or SSO URL, please see Microsoft's AD FS 2.0 RelayState article.

Note: When adding your identify provider (IdP) SSO target URL to the SAML settings in your KSAT console, it should follow this format: https://samportal.example_domain.com/adfs/ls/idpinitiatedsignon.aspx?logintoRP=KnowBe4. Your ADFS server should follow this format: samportal.example_domain.com = FQDN.

images.alt:
The image is a screen capture of a management console (likely an MMC snap-in for identity or federation services), displaying a context menu over a portion of the navigation tree and content pane.

**Context and UI Elements:**
The left pane (partially visible) shows nodes for "Trust Relationships" and "Claims Provider Trusts." A context menu is open, initiated from a selected folder related to trust configuration.

**Context Menu Items (Top to Bottom):**
1. **Add Relying Party Trust...** (Indicates initiation of a configuration wizard/dialog).
2. **Add Non-Claims-Aware Relying Party Trust...** (Indicates initiation of a configuration wizard/dialog).
3. **View** (Includes a right-facing arrow, denoting a submenu).
4. **New Window from Here**
5. **Refresh**
6. **Help**

**Annotation:**
The menu option **"Add Relying Party Trust..."** is circled with an orange elliptical marker and pointed to by a thick orange arrow, emphasizing this specific action.
images.context: When you click, the Add Relying Party Trust window will open.

images.alt:
This image displays the initial state of the **"Add Relying Party Trust Wizard,"** a configuration utility for Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS).

**Context and Title:**
The dialog box title is "Add Relying Party Trust Wizard," indicating the initiation of a process to establish a trust relationship with a relying party application for claims issuance.

**UI Elements (Steps Pane):**
The left pane lists the wizard steps:
1. Welcome (Green status indicator)
2. Select Data Source (Green status indicator)
3. Configure Multi-factor Authentication Now? (Blue status indicator)
4. Choose Issuance Authorization Rules (Blue status indicator)
5. Ready to Add Trust (Blue status indicator)
6. Finish (Blue status indicator)

**Main Content (Welcome Screen):**
The primary panel displays the "Welcome to the Add Relying Party Trust Wizard" heading. The accompanying text defines the technical purpose: "This wizard will help you add a new relying party trust to the AD FS configuration database. Relying parties consume claims in security tokens that are issued by this Federation Service to make authentication and authorization decisions." It further notes that the process defines recognition parameters and that issuance transform rules can be defined later.

**Navigation Controls:**
The footer contains three standard wizard controls:
*   `< Previous` (Dimmed/inactive)
*   `Start` (Primary action button, active)
*   `Cancel` (Active)

The user must click the **Start** button to proceed with the configuration process.
images.context:
' '>

Click Start on the wizard’s Welcome screen.

images.alt:
This image displays the **"Select Data Source"** step within the **"Add Relying Party Trust Wizard"** interface, typically associated with Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) configuration.

**Context and Navigation:**
*   The wizard title is **"Add Relying Party Trust Wizard."**
*   The left navigation pane lists the steps. **"Welcome"** and **"Select Data Source"** are marked complete (green circles), with **"Select Data Source"** currently active. Subsequent steps (e.g., "Specify Display Name," "Choose Profile," "Configure Certificate") are pending (blue circles).

**Main Content Area (Select Data Source):**
The instruction text is **"Select an option that this wizard will use to obtain data about this relying party:"**

Three radio button options for metadata acquisition are presented:

1.  **Import data about the relying party published online or on a local network:** Requires a URL input field labeled **"Federation metadata address (host name or URL):"** (Unselected).
2.  **Import data about the relying party from a file:** Requires a file path input field labeled **"Federation metadata file location:"** followed by a **"Browse..."** button (Unselected).
3.  **Enter data about the relying party manually:** This option is currently selected. The descriptive text states: **"Use this option to manually input the necessary data about this relying party organization."**

**Footer Controls:**
The navigation buttons available are **"< Previous," "Next >,"** and **"Cancel."**
images.context: Click Next.

images.alt:
This image displays the "Specify Display Name" step within the "Add Relying Party Trust Wizard," indicating the configuration process for a relying party trust, likely within Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) or similar identity management software.

**UI Context and Status:**

*   **Window Title:** Add Relying Party Trust Wizard.
*   **Active Step:** "Specify Display Name," highlighted in the left navigation pane. Previous steps ("Welcome" and "Select Data Source") are marked complete with green indicators.
*   **Pending Steps:** Eight subsequent steps are listed, marked with blue indicators (e.g., Choose Profile, Configure Certificate, Configure Identifiers).

**Data Input Fields:**

The main content area presents the instruction: "Enter the display name and any optional notes for this relying party."

1.  **Display name:** A single-line text field populated with the entry: `KnowBe4`.
2.  **Notes:** A large, multi-line text area designated for optional notes.

**Navigation Controls:**

The lower right corner contains standard wizard controls:

*   `< Previous` button.
*   `Next >` button (visually highlighted, indicating the likely action to be taken).
*   `Cancel` button.
images.context: Select Next.

images.alt:
This image displays a step within a configuration wizard, titled "**Add Relying Party Trust Wizard**." The specific step is "**Choose Profile**," highlighted in the left navigation pane.

**UI Elements and Context:**

*   **Wizard Title:** Add Relying Party Trust Wizard.
*   **Current Step (Navigation Pane):** A vertical list of steps on the left. The current step, "**Choose Profile**," is selected and marked with a green checkmark, indicating previous steps are complete. Completed steps include: Welcome, Select Data Source, and Specify Display Name. Subsequent, uncompleted steps are marked with blue circles.
*   **Instructional Text:** "This wizard uses configuration profiles to aid in creating the relying party trust. Choose the appropriate configuration profile for this relying party trust."

**Interactive Elements (Options):**

The user is presented with two mutually exclusive radio button options to select a profile:

1.  **[Selected] AD FS profile**
    *   *Description:* "This profile supports relying parties that are interoperable with new AD FS features, such as security token encryption and the SAML 2.0 protocol." (This option is currently selected, indicated by the filled radio button and highlighted by an orange circle and arrow.)
2.  **AD FS 1.0 and 1.1 profile**
    *   *Description:* "This profile supports relying parties that are interoperable with AD FS 1.0 and 1.1."

**Action Buttons (Footer):**

At the bottom right, standard wizard navigation controls are present:

*   `< Previous`
*   `Next >` (Highlighted by an orange circle and arrow, indicating the typical action to proceed.)
*   `Cancel`
images.context:
'>

Leave AD FS profile selected and select Next.

images.alt:
The image displays the **"Add Relying Party Trust Wizard,"** configured to the **"Configure Certificate"** step.

**UI Context and Status:**

1.  **Wizard Title:** Add Relying Party Trust Wizard.
2.  **Steps Pane (Left):** The vertical navigation pane shows five steps are complete (indicated by green checkmarks: Welcome, Select Data Source, Specify Display Name, Choose Profile, Configure Certificate). The current highlighted step is **Configure Certificate**. Seven subsequent steps are pending (indicated by blue dots).
3.  **Current Configuration View:** The main content area is titled **Configure Certificate**.

**Configuration Elements and Text:**

1.  **Instructions:** The descriptive text explains: "Specify an optional token encryption certificate. The token encryption certificate is used to encrypt the claims that are sent to this relying party. The relying party will use the private key of this certificate to decrypt the claims that are sent to it. To specify the certificate, click Browse..."
2.  **Certificate Display Fields:** Below the instructions, placeholder labels are visible for displaying certificate metadata:
    *   Issuer:
    *   Subject:
    *   Effective date:
    *   Expiration date:
3.  **Action Buttons (Certificate):** Three buttons are provided to manage the certificate selection: `View...`, **`Browse...`** (the primary action button for this step), and `Remove`.

**Wizard Navigation Controls:**

The footer contains the standard wizard navigation controls: `< Previous`, **`Next >`** (highlighted as the primary continuation action), and `Cancel`.
images.context:
a>

On the Configure Certificate screen, select Next.

images.alt:
The image displays the **"Add Relying Party Trust Wizard"** within a server configuration environment (likely ADFS). The active step, highlighted in the left navigation pane, is **"Configure URL."**

**UI Elements and Configuration Details:**

*   **Steps Pane:** Shows configuration progress, with steps through "Configure Certificate" complete (green) and steps from "Configure URL" through "Finish" listed as upcoming or current (blue/active).
*   **Protocol Selection:** The panel allows selection between WS-Federation and SAML protocols.
    *   The checkbox for "Enable support for the WS-Federation Passive protocol" is **unchecked**.
    *   The checkbox for **"Enable support for the SAML 2.0 WebSSO protocol"** is **checked**.
*   **SAML Configuration:** The text field labeled **"Relying party SAML 2.0 SSO service URL:"** contains the required endpoint: `https://training.knowbe4.com/auth/saml/xxxxxxxxx/callback`.
*   **Instructional Overlay:** A prominent, non-UI annotation points to the SAML URL field, instructing the user to **"Enter your unique Callback URL from your KnowBe4 Account Settings."**
*   **Navigation Controls:** The wizard footer includes the `< Previous`, `Next >`, and `Cancel` buttons.
images.context: vice URL field on the Configure URL page and select Next.

images.alt:
This image displays the **Configure Identifiers** step within the **Add Relying Party Trust Wizard**, characteristic of Windows Server identity management environments (e.g., AD FS).

**Context and Navigation Status:**
The wizard is on Step 7, **Configure Identifiers**, indicated by the highlighted entry and green status dot in the left-hand navigation pane. Previous steps (Welcome through Configure URL) are complete.

**UI Elements and Input Data:**
The main pane facilitates adding identifiers for the relying party trust.

1.  **Input Field:** Labeled "Relying party trust identifier:", designed to accept a unique string or URI (Example: `https://fs.contoso.com/adfs/services/trust`).
2.  **List Field:** Labeled "Relying party trust identifiers:". This field displays currently configured identifiers. One identifier, **"KnowBe4"**, is already listed and selected.
3.  **Action Buttons:**
    *   An **"Add"** button is available next to the input field to commit the entered identifier to the list.
    *   A **"Remove"** button is available next to the list field to delete selected identifiers.

**Required Action and Navigation:**
The illustrated action confirms the identifier **"KnowBe4"** has been added to the trust list. The user is prompted to proceed by clicking the **"Next >"** button, located in the lower right corner of the wizard window.
images.context: Select Add, then select Next.

images.alt:
The image displays the **"Add Relying Party Trust Wizard"** interface, specifically on the **"Configure Multi-factor Authentication Now?"** step.

**UI Elements and Context:**

1.  **Navigation Pane (Left):** Lists wizard steps. Steps from "Welcome" through "Configure Multi-factor Authentication Now?" are marked as completed (green check/dot). The current step is highlighted. Subsequent steps ("Choose Issuance Authorization Rules," "Ready to Add Trust," "Finish") are pending (blue dot).
2.  **Configuration Content (Center):** The primary view displays information regarding multi-factor authentication (MFA) requirements. Introductory text states, "Configure multi-factor authentication settings for this relying party trust. Multi-factor authentication is required if there is a match for any of the specified requirements."
3.  **Status Table:** A table titled **"Multi-factor Authentication"** shows "Global Settings" for specific "Requirements":
    *   Users/Groups: Not configured
    *   Device: Not configured
    *   Location: Not configured
4.  **User Input (Radio Buttons):** The user is presented with two mutually exclusive options, with the first selected by default:
    *   **(Selected)** I do not want to configure multi-factor authentication settings for this relying party trust at this time.
    *   Configure multi-factor authentication settings for this relying party trust.
5.  **Supplemental Information:** A note advises the user that MFA can also be configured by navigating to the "Authentication Policies node," with a linked reference to "Configuring Authentication Policies."
6.  **Navigation Controls (Bottom):** Standard wizard navigation buttons are present: `< Previous`, `Next >`, and `Cancel`.
images.context: r this relying party trust at this time option selected, then select Next.

images.alt:
This is a screenshot of the **Add Relying Party Trust Wizard**, specifically the **Choose Issuance Authorization Rules** step within a Windows Server/AD FS (Active Directory Federation Services) environment.

**UI Elements and Context:**

*   **Wizard Title:** "Add Relying Party Trust Wizard."
*   **Step Header:** "Choose Issuance Authorization Rules."
*   **Navigation Pane (Steps):** A left-hand vertical list tracks the progress. Steps 1 through 10 are marked complete (green circles), including "Configure Multi-factor Authentication Now?" and the current step, "Choose Issuance Authorization Rules" (highlighted blue text with a green circle). Steps 11 and 12, "Ready to Add Trust" and "Finish," are marked as pending (blue circles).
*   **Main Content:** Provides introductory text and radio button options for configuring issuance authorization.

**Key Text and Options:**

*   **Instructional Text:** "Issuance authorization rules determine whether a user is permitted to receive claims for the relying party. Choose one of the following options for the initial behavior of this relying party's issuance authorization rules."
*   **Option 1 (Selected):** **"Permit all users to access this relying party"** (Selected via a radio button).
    *   *Descriptive Subtext:* "The issuance authorization rules will be configured to permit all users to access this relying party. The relying party service or application may still deny the user access." (This option is highlighted by an orange selection circle and arrow).
*   **Option 2 (Unselected):** **"Deny all users access to this relying party"** (Unselected via a radio button).
    *   *Descriptive Subtext:* "The issuance authorization rules will be configured to deny all users access to this relying party. You must later add issuance authorization rules to enable any users to access this relying party."
*   **Footer Navigation Buttons:** Standard wizard buttons are present: **< Previous**, **Next >** (currently active/clickable), and **Cancel**.
images.context: all users to access this relying party option selected, then select Next.

images.alt:
This image displays the final configuration screen, "Ready to Add Trust," within the **Add Relying Party Trust Wizard**. This appears to be a management console interface, likely for Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS).

**UI Elements and Context:**

*   **Wizard Title:** "Add Relying Party Trust Wizard."
*   **Navigation Pane (Left):** A vertical "Steps" list tracks progress through the wizard. All prior steps are marked with a green circle, indicating completion:
    *   Welcome
    *   Select Data Source
    *   Specify Display Name
    *   Choose Profile
    *   Configure Certificate
    *   Configure URL
    *   Configure Identifiers
    *   Configure Multi-factor Authentication Now?
    *   Choose Issuance Authorization Rules
    *   **Ready to Add Trust** (Currently selected, highlighted in gray, marked with a green circle)
    *   Finish (Marked with a blue circle, pending completion)
*   **Main Content Area:**
    *   **Section Title:** "Ready to Add Trust."
    *   **Instruction Text:** "The relying party trust has been configured. Review the following settings, and then click Next to add the relying party trust to the AD FS configuration database."
    *   **Configuration Review Tabs:** A set of horizontal tabs allows review of different aspects of the configuration. The currently selected tab is **Monitoring**. Other visible tabs include: Identifiers, Encryption, Signature, Accepted Claims, Organization, Endpoints, and Notes (with scroll arrows indicating more tabs may be hidden).
    *   **Monitoring Tab Content:**
        *   **Header:** "Specify the monitoring settings for this relying party trust."
        *   **Input Field:** "Relying party's federation metadata URL:" (followed by an empty, editable text box).
        *   **Checkboxes:**
            *   [ ] Monitor relying party
            *   [ ] Automatically update relying party (indented under the first checkbox)
        *   **Status Text:**
            *   "This relying party's federation metadata data was last checked on: **< never >**"
            *   "This relying party was last updated from federation metadata on: **< never >**"
*   **Action Buttons (Bottom):** Standard wizard navigation buttons are present:
    *   `< Previous` (Enabled)
    *   `Next >` (Enabled and highlighted by an orange arrow in the image, indicating the recommended action to proceed with configuration)
    *   `Cancel` (Enabled)
images.context:
>

On the Ready to Add Trust screen, select Next.

images.alt:
This image displays the **Finish** step of the Windows Server **Add Relying Party Trust Wizard**.

**Context and Heading:**
*   **Wizard Title:** Add Relying Party Trust Wizard
*   **Current Step:** Finish (highlighted in the left navigation pane).

**Left Navigation (Steps):**
The navigation pane lists 12 steps, all marked with green success indicators, signifying completion:
1.  Welcome
2.  Select Data Source
3.  Specify Display Name
4.  Choose Profile
5.  Configure Certificate
6.  Configure URL
7.  Configure Identifiers
8.  Configure Multi-factor Authentication Now?
9.  Choose Issuance Authorization Rules
10. Ready to Add Trust
11. Finish

**Main Content Area (Confirmation):**
The text confirms the action was successful:
*   "The relying party trust was successfully added to the AD FS configuration database."
*   "You can modify this relying party trust by using the Properties dialog box in the AD FS Management snap-in."

**Key UI Element (Checkbox):**
A checkbox is present below the confirmation text:
*   **State:** Checked (default or user-selected).
*   **Label:** "Open the Edit Claim Rules dialog for this relying party trust when the wizard closes"
*(Note: An orange arrow and oval annotation highlights this checkbox.)*

**Action Button:**
At the bottom right corner, the final button for the wizard is displayed:
*   **Label:** Close
*(Note: A second orange arrow and oval annotation highlights this button.)*
images.context: ng party trust when the wizard closes check box selected and select Close.

images.alt:
This image displays a configuration dialog titled "Issuance Transform Rules," which is the active tab among three visible tabs: "Issuance Transform Rules," "Issuance Authorization Rules," and "Delegation Authorization Rules."

The dialog features the instructional text: "The following transform rules specify the claims that will be sent to the relying party."

A main data grid is present, currently empty, with column headers: **Order**, **Rule Name**, and **Issued Claims**. Vertical arrow buttons are positioned to the right of the grid for rule reordering (Up and Down).

Below the grid are the rule management buttons:
1.  **Add Rule...** (Active)
2.  **Edit Rule...** (Present)
3.  **Remove Rule...** (Present)

The "Add Rule..." button is visually emphasized in the original image via an overlay arrow and circle, indicating it as the point of user action.

Standard window action buttons are located at the bottom right: **OK**, **Cancel**, and **Apply**.
images.context:
a>

In the Edit claim rules window, select Add Rule….

images.alt:
This image displays the **"Select Rule Template"** screen within the **"Add Transform Claim Rule Wizard,"** typically associated with identity management systems like Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS).

**UI Layout and Context:**

*   **Window Title:** "Add Transform Claim Rule Wizard."
*   **Navigation Panel (Steps):** A left-hand navigation pane indicates progress. **"Choose Rule Type"** is marked as completed (green indicator), and **"Configure Claim Rule"** is the currently selected step (blue indicator).
*   **Instruction Text:** The main content area instructs the user to "Select the template for the claim rule that you want to create from the following list."

**Key Elements and Text:**

*   **Claim Rule Template Selection:** The dropdown menu labeled **"Claim rule template:"** is pre-selected with the value **"Send LDAP Attributes as Claims."**
*   **Claim Rule Template Description:** A large read-only text box below the selection provides technical details. The description explains that this rule template allows selecting attributes from an LDAP store (e.g., Active Directory attributes such as `displayName` and `telephoneNumber`) to be sent as outgoing claims to a relying party. It notes that multiple attributes can be sent as claims from a single rule execution.

**Action Buttons:**

*   The footer contains standard wizard navigation controls: **`< Previous`**, **`Next >`** (highlighted, indicating the recommended action to proceed with configuration), and **`Cancel`**.
images.context: g>Send LDAP Attributes as Claims selected as the template and select Next.

images.alt:
This image displays the **"Configure Rule"** step within the **"Add Transform Claim Rule Wizard,"** a UI for configuring claims processing rules, likely within an identity management or federation service environment (e.g., ADFS).

**Header and Context:**
*   **Wizard Title:** Add Transform Claim Rule Wizard.
*   **Step Title:** Configure Rule.
*   **Steps Panel (Left):** Shows "Choose Rule Type" and "Configure Claim Rule" as completed steps (indicated by green checkmarks).
*   **Instruction Text:** "You can configure this rule to send the values of LDAP attributes as claims. Select an attribute store from which to extract LDAP attributes. Specify how the attributes will map to the outgoing claim types that will be issued from the rule."

**Input Fields and Configuration:**
1.  **Claim rule name:** A text input field populated with the value **"Email"**.
2.  **Rule template:** Displays static text: **"Send LDAP Attributes as Claims"**.
3.  **Attribute store:** A dropdown menu currently selected to **"Active Directory"**.
4.  **Mapping of LDAP attributes to outgoing claim types:** A table structure for defining attribute mapping.
    *   The table contains two columns: **"LDAP Attribute (Select or type to add more)"** and **"Outgoing Claim Type (Select or type to add more)"**.
    *   **Row 1 (Configured Rule):**
        *   LDAP Attribute: **"E-Mail-Addresses"**
        *   Outgoing Claim Type: **"E-Mail Address"** (Highlighted/selected).
    *   **Row 2 (New Entry):** Marked with an asterisk (\*) indicating a field for adding a new mapping.

**Navigation and Actions:**
*   **Buttons (Bottom Right):** `< Previous`, **Finish** (currently highlighted/active), and `Cancel`.
images.context: Click Finish.

images.alt:
This image depicts a modal dialog or settings pane, specifically configured for managing identity claim issuance rules.

**Context and Header:**
*   The interface utilizes a tab structure with three tabs visible: **Issuance Transform Rules** (active), **Issuance Authorization Rules**, and **Delegation Authorization Rules**.
*   A descriptive sentence reads: "The following transform rules specify the claims that will be sent to the relying party."

**Rule Management Table:**
*   A data grid displays existing rules under three columns: **Order**, **Rule Name**, and **Issued Claims**.
*   One rule is currently highlighted (selected):
    *   **Order:** 1
    *   **Rule Name:** Email
    *   **Issued Claims:** E-Mail Address
*   To the right of the grid, two arrow buttons (up and down) are provided for reordering the rules.

**Action Buttons (Rule Management):**
*   Below the grid, three command buttons facilitate rule modification:
    *   **Add Rule...** (Highlighted by an orange circle and arrow, indicating a primary action or current focus)
    *   **Edit Rule...**
    *   **Remove Rule...**

**Dialog Controls:**
*   At the bottom of the pane, standard navigational controls are present:
    *   **OK**
    *   **Cancel**
    *   **Apply**
images.context: back on the Edit Claims window again.

images.alt:
The image displays a modal window titled "**Add Transform Claim Rule Wizard**" on the "**Select Rule Template**" page.

**Wizard Steps:**
The navigation pane shows two steps:
1. **Choose Rule Type** (Completed, indicated by a green circle).
2. **Configure Claim Rule** (Active step, indicated by a blue circle).

**UI Elements and Configuration:**
The main instructional text directs the user to "Select the template for the claim rule."
*   **Claim rule template:** A dropdown field is visible, currently displaying the selected option: "**Transform an Incoming Claim**."
*   **Claim rule template description:** A text box details the functionality of the selected rule. The description explains that the template allows the user to select an incoming claim, change its claim type, and optionally change its claim value. It provides specific examples, such as transforming an incoming group claim with a value of 'Admins' into a group claim with a value of 'Purchasers'.

**Navigation Controls:**
The bottom of the wizard contains standard navigation buttons:
*   `< Previous`
*   `Next >` (Highlighted as the active continuation button)
*   `Cancel`
images.context: late, select Transform an Incoming Claim and select Next.

images.alt:
This image displays the **"Configure Rule"** step within the **"Add Transform Claim Rule Wizard,"** a configuration interface for defining claim mapping logic.

**Wizard Context and Steps:**
The navigation pane indicates the user is on the second step, **"Configure Claim Rule,"** following the completed **"Choose Rule Type"** step.

**Instructional Text:**
The primary text instructs the user: "You can configure this rule to map an incoming claim type to an outgoing claim type. As an option, you can also map an incoming claim value to an outgoing claim value. Specify the incoming claim type to map to the outgoing claim type and whether the claim value should be mapped to a new claim value."

**Rule Definition:**
*   **Claim rule name:** Textbox defaults to "Transform".
*   **Rule template:** Static text field displays "Transform an Incoming Claim".

**Claim Mapping Configuration:**
The following fields define the transformation of the claim type:
*   **Incoming claim type:** Dropdown selected to **"E-Mail Address"**.
*   **Incoming name ID format:** Dropdown selected to **"Unspecified"**.
*   **Outgoing claim type:** Dropdown selected to **"Name ID"**.
*   **Outgoing name ID format:** Dropdown selected to **"Email"**.

**Claim Value Options (Selected Handling):**
Three radio button options control how claim values are processed. The default selection is:
*   **Pass through all claim values** (Selected).

The two remaining options, which are currently inactive (grayed out), are:
*   Replace an incoming claim value with a different outgoing claim value (with associated **Incoming claim value**, **Outgoing claim value** textboxes, and a **Browse...** button).
*   Replace incoming e-mail suffix claims with a new e-mail suffix (with an associated **New e-mail suffix** textbox, including the example "fabrikam.com").

**Navigation Controls (Footer):**
The footer contains the standard wizard navigation buttons: **< Previous**, **Finish** (highlighted), and **Cancel**.

This image displays a user interface snippet, likely from a management console (e.g., AD FS), showing a context menu opened over a selected configuration item.

**UI Elements and Context:**

*   **List View (Left):** The list view shows configuration entities. The item **"KnowBe4"** is selected and highlighted in blue, indicating it is the target of the action. Other visible list items include "Device Registration Service" and "AuthenticationServer".
*   **Context Menu (Right):** A vertical context menu is displayed, offering actions related to the selected entity.
*   **Selected Action:** The menu item **"Properties"** is highlighted with an orange border, indicating it is currently selected or about to be clicked.

**Menu Text:**

The context menu options, from top to bottom, are:

1.  Update from Federation Metadata...
2.  Edit Claim Rules...
3.  Disable
4.  **Properties** (Highlighted)
5.  *(Separator Line)*
6.  Delete
7.  Help

**Overall State:**
The image captures the moment a user has right-clicked the "KnowBe4" entity and is selecting the "Properties" option to access detailed configuration settings.

The image displays the **KnowBe4 Properties** configuration dialog box.

**Window Context:**
*   **Title Bar:** KnowBe4 Properties
*   **Active Tab:** Advanced (Part of a secondary row of tabs, following Accepted Claims, Organization, Endpoints, and Notes. Primary tabs include Monitoring, Identifiers, Encryption, and Signature).

**Configuration Details (Advanced Tab):**
*   **Instructional Text:** "Specify the secure hash algorithm to use for this relying party trust."
*   **Setting Field:** Secure hash algorithm:
*   **Value:** A dropdown selector (combo box) is used for this field, with the current selected value being **SHA-256**.

**Action Buttons (Footer):**
*   The standard action buttons are visible: **OK**, Cancel, Apply, and Help.
images.context: and select SHA-256 from the Secure hash algorithm drop-down menu.

images.alt:
The image displays the **AD FS 2.0 Management Console (MMC)** interface, specifically showing the configuration of certificates.

**UI Context and Navigation:**
The primary window is titled "AD FS 2.0." The left-hand navigation pane shows the tree structure, with the **Certificates** node selected under the **Service** configuration group.

**Certificates Details Pane (Center):**
The center pane lists certificates categorized by role, including columns for Subject, Issuer, Effective Date, Expiration Date, Status, and Primary designation.

1.  **Service communications:** Contains one entry with Subject/Issuer `CN=Dev-General01.DevKB4a.com`. Effective Date: 5/3/2016. Expiration Date: 5/2/2017.
2.  **Token-decrypting:** Contains one entry with Subject/Issuer `CN=ADFS Encryption - Dev-General01.DevKB4a.com`. Designated as "Primary." Dates: 5/3/2016 to 5/3/2017.
3.  **Token-signing:** This entry is highlighted (selected) and has the Subject/Issuer `CN=ADFS Signing - Dev-General01.DevKB4a.com`. Designated as "Primary." Dates: 5/3/2016 to 5/3/2017.

**Actions Pane (Right):**
The Actions pane lists operations relevant to the selected context.

*   **General Certificate Actions:** Includes options to `Add Token-Signing ...`, `Add Token-Decrypti...`, `Set Service Commu...`, and `Refresh`.
*   **Selected Certificate Actions:** Actions specific to the highlighted Token-signing certificate are listed, including `View Certificate...` and `Set as Primary` (which appears inactive, confirming the current primary status).

images.alt:
The image displays the standard Windows **Certificate** property dialog box, with the **Details** tab currently selected.

**UI Structure and Content:**

1.  **Tabs:** Three primary tabs are visible: General, Details (active), and Certification Path.
2.  **Filter:** A dropdown menu labeled "Show:" is set to `<All>`.
3.  **Field/Value List:** A two-column view lists certificate attributes. Key visible fields and their corresponding values include:
    *   **Signature hash algorithm:** sha256
    *   **Issuer:** ADFS Encryption - Dev-Gener...
    *   **Valid from/to:** Dates spanning May 2016 to May 2017.
    *   **Public key:** RSA (2048 Bits)
    *   **Thumbprint algorithm:** sha1
    *   **Thumbprint:** (This field is selected and highlighted).
4.  **Details Pane (Thumbprint Value):** The pane below the list displays the detailed value for the selected Thumbprint field, labeled "Sample SHA1 Thumbprint:"
    *   **Value:** `6b 30 ff 92 f7 84 ce 34 46 ba 8b bc 45 b8 cd 6a 01 a5 9a 81` (a hexadecimal string).
5.  **Actions and Navigation:**
    *   A hyperlink reads: "Learn more about **certificate details**".
    *   The **Edit Properties...** button is disabled (greyed out).
    *   Enabled action buttons are **Copy to File...** and **OK**.
